title: Misplacing question mark operator throws `field expressions cannot have generic arguments`

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code:

```rust
fn foo() -> Result<Vec<()>, ()> {
    let foos = []
        .into_iter()
        .collect::<Result<_, ()>>?();
    
    Ok(foos)
}
```

([playground link](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=b5a29a229b0ec891805824f83ec0460f))

The current output is:

```
error: field expressions cannot have generic arguments
 --> src/lib.rs:4:19
  |
4 |         .collect::<Result<_, ()>>?();
  |                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

error[E0615]: attempted to take value of method `collect` on type `std::array::IntoIter<_, 0_usize>`
 --> src/lib.rs:4:10
  |
4 |         .collect::<Result<_, ()>>?();
  |          ^^^^^^^ method, not a field
  |
help: use parentheses to call the method
  |
4 |         .collect::<Result<_, ()>>()?();
  |                                  ++
```

Ideally the output could look like:

```
error: field expressions cannot have generic arguments
 --> src/lib.rs:4:19
  |
4 |         .collect::<Result<_, ()>>?();
  |                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

hint: move the question mark operator after the parentheses:
 --> src/lib.rs:4:19
  |
4 |         .collect::<Result<_, ()>>?();
  -                                  ^
4 |         .collect::<Result<_, ()>>()?;
  +                                    ^
```

I'd consider myself a seasoned programmer, but with the current error message it nonetheless took me a while to notice the error, especially since I swear it's the first time I see the `field expressions cannot have generic arguments` message 😅
